Improving the design and functionality of your website to make it more user-friendly, especially for new hire recruits who need to download, fill out, and email back files, is a great goal. While I cannot directly view or interact with your website (as I cannot browse the internet), I can provide general suggestions based on common best practices for improving website design and user experience (UX). Here’s how you can enhance your website to make it more "magnificent" and functional:

1. Simplify the Navigation

  • Problem: If new hires are struggling to find and download files, the navigation might be unclear or overly complex.

  • Solution:

    • Create a dedicated section for New Hire Resources or Employee Resources in the main menu.

    • Use clear, concise labels like "New Hire Forms," "Download Resources," or "Employee Onboarding."

    • Ensure the navigation is intuitive and accessible from every page.

2. Improve File Accessibility

  • Problem: If files are hard to download or locate, the process needs to be streamlined.

  • Solution:

    • Organize files into clearly labeled categories (e.g., "Tax Forms," "Onboarding Documents," "Training Materials").

    • Provide a Download All button for convenience, or a zip file containing all necessary documents.

    • Ensure files are in user-friendly formats (e.g., PDF for forms, Word documents for editable files).

3. Enhance Visual Design

  • Problem: A dated or cluttered design can make the website less appealing and harder to use.

  • Solution:

    • Use a modern, clean layout with plenty of white space to avoid overwhelming users.

    • Incorporate your brand colors and professional imagery (e.g., healthcare-related visuals).

    • Add icons or visuals next to download links to make them stand out.

4. Add Clear Instructions

  • Problem: New hires might not know how to download, fill out, and email forms back.

  • Solution:

    • Include step-by-step instructions on the page (e.g., "Step 1: Download the form. Step 2: Fill it out. Step 3: Email it to [email address].").

    • Provide a sample of a correctly filled-out form for reference.

    • Add a FAQ section addressing common questions about the process.

5. Optimize for Mobile Devices

  • Problem: If the website isn’t mobile-friendly, users on phones or tablets will struggle.

  • Solution:

    • Ensure the website is fully responsive, meaning it adapts to different screen sizes.

    • Test all download links and forms on mobile devices to ensure they work seamlessly.

6. Add a Contact or Support Section

  • Problem: If users encounter issues, they need a way to get help.

  • Solution:

    • Include a Contact Us button or link prominently on the page.

    • Provide a direct email or phone number for HR or IT support.

    • Consider adding a live chat feature for real-time assistance.

7. Use Call-to-Action (CTA) Buttons

  • Problem: Users might not know where to click to complete tasks.

  • Solution:

    • Use bold, eye-catching CTA buttons like:

      • "Download New Hire Forms"

      • "Email Completed Forms Here"

      • "Get Help with Onboarding"

    • Place these buttons prominently on the page.

8. Test and Iterate

  • Problem: Without testing, you won’t know if the changes are effective.

  • Solution:

    • Conduct usability testing with new hires to identify pain points.

    • Gather feedback and make iterative improvements.

9. Add a Progress Tracker

  • Problem: New hires might feel overwhelmed by the onboarding process.

  • Solution:

    • Include a progress tracker or checklist (e.g., "Step 1: Download Forms → Step 2: Complete Training → Step 3: Submit Documents").

    • This helps users understand where they are in the process and what’s next.

10. Consider a Portal or Dashboard

  • Problem: If the process is still too cumbersome, a more advanced solution might be needed.

  • Solution:

    • Create a secure employee portal where new hires can log in, access forms, and submit them directly.

    • Use tools like Google Forms, Microsoft Forms, or specialized HR software to streamline the process.

JavaScript (frontend/scripts/script.js)

This will handle login, GPS tracking, and sign-in/sign-out functionality.

javascript
Copy
document.getElementById('login-form').addEventListener('submit', async (e) => {
  e.preventDefault();
  const email = document.getElementById('email').value;
  const password = document.getElementById('password').value;

  // Send login request to backend
  const response = await fetch('/api/login', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({ email, password }),
  });

  const data = await response.json();
  if (response.ok) {
    localStorage.setItem('token', data.token);
    showDashboard(data.employee);
  } else {
    alert(data.message);
  }
});

function showDashboard(employee) {
  document.getElementById('login').classList.add('hidden');
  document.getElementById('dashboard').classList.remove('hidden');
  document.getElementById('employee-name').textContent = employee.name;
}

document.getElementById('sign-in-btn').addEventListener('click', async () => {
  const position = await getLocation();
  const response = await fetch('/api/sign-in', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: {
      'Content-Type': 'application/json',
      'Authorization': `Bearer ${localStorage.getItem('token')}`,
    },
    body: JSON.stringify({ latitude: position.coords.latitude, longitude: position.coords.longitude }),
  });

  const data = await response.json();
  if (response.ok) {
    document.getElementById('sign-in-btn').classList.add('hidden');
    document.getElementById('sign-out-btn').classList.remove('hidden');
    document.getElementById('status-message').textContent = 'You are signed in.';
  } else {
    alert(data.message);
  }
});

document.getElementById('sign-out-btn').addEventListener('click', async () => {
  const position = await getLocation();
  const response = await fetch('/api/sign-out', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: {
      'Content-Type': 'application/json',
      'Authorization': `Bearer ${localStorage.getItem('token')}`,
    },
    body: JSON.stringify({ latitude: position.coords.latitude, longitude: position.coords.longitude }),
  });

  const data = await response.json();
  if (response.ok) {
    document.getElementById('sign-out-btn').classList.add('hidden');
    document.getElementById('sign-in-btn').classList.remove('hidden');
    document.getElementById('status-message').textContent = 'You are signed out.';
  } else {
    alert(data.message);
  }
});

function getLocation() {
  return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    if (!navigator.geolocation) {
      reject('Geolocation is not supported by your browser.');
    } else {
      navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(resolve, reject);
    }
  });
}

3. Backend (Node.js with Express.js)

Install Dependencies

Run the following commands in your backend folder:

bash
Copy
npm init -y
npm install express mongoose bcryptjs jsonwebtoken cors

Backend Code (backend/server.js)

This will handle authentication, sign-in/sign-out, and GPS tracking.

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const mongoose = require('mongoose');
const bcrypt = require('bcryptjs');
const jwt = require('jsonwebtoken');
const cors = require('cors');
const app = express();

app.use(express.json());
app.use(cors());

// Connect to MongoDB
mongoose.connect('mongodb://localhost:27017/firstchoicehcmi', {
  useNewUrlParser: true,
  useUnifiedTopology: true,
});

// Employee Schema
const employeeSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: String,
  email: { type: String, unique: true },
  password: String,
  signInLogs: [{ timestamp: Date, location: { latitude: Number, longitude: Number } }],
  signOutLogs: [{ timestamp: Date, location: { latitude: Number, longitude: Number } }],
});

const Employee = mongoose.model('Employee', employeeSchema);

// Routes
app.post('/api/login', async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  const employee = await Employee.findOne({ email });
  if (!employee || !bcrypt.compareSync(password, employee.password)) {
    return res.status(401).json({ message: 'Invalid email or password' });
  }
  const token = jwt.sign({ id: employee._id }, 'secret_key');
  res.json({ token, employee: { name: employee.name } });
});

app.post('/api/sign-in', async (req, res) => {
  const { latitude, longitude } = req.body;
  const token = req.headers.authorization.split(' ')[1];
  const decoded = jwt.verify(token, 'secret_key');
  const employee = await Employee.findById(decoded.id);
  employee.signInLogs.push({ timestamp: new Date(), location: { latitude, longitude } });
  await employee.save();
  res.json({ message: 'Signed in successfully' });
});

app.post('/api/sign-out', async (req, res) => {
  const { latitude, longitude } = req.body;
  const token = req.headers.authorization.split(' ')[1];
  const decoded = jwt.verify(token, 'secret_key');
  const employee = await Employee.findById(decoded.id);
  employee.signOutLogs.push({ timestamp: new Date(), location: { latitude, longitude } });
  await employee.save();
  res.json({ message: 'Signed out successfully' });
});

// Start Server
app.listen(5000, () => console.log('Server running on http://localhost:5000'));

Step 1: Deployment

We’ll deploy the application using Heroku (for backend) and Netlify (for frontend). Both platforms offer free tiers and are beginner-friendly.

1.1 Deploy Backend to Heroku

  1. Create a Heroku Account: Sign up at Heroku.

  2. Install Heroku CLI: Download and install from here.

  3. Login to Heroku:

    bash
    Copy
    heroku login

  4. Create a New Heroku App:

    bash
    Copy
    heroku create firstchoicehcmi-backend

  5. Add MongoDB Database:

    • Use MongoDB Atlas (free tier) or Heroku Add-ons like mLab.

    • Update the MongoDB connection string in backend/server.js:

      javascript
      Copy
      mongoose.connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI || 'mongodb://localhost:27017/firstchoicehcmi', {
  useNewUrlParser: true,
  useUnifiedTopology: true,
});

  6. Set Environment Variables:

    • Go to your Heroku dashboard → Settings → Config Vars.

    • Add MONGODB_URI (your MongoDB connection string) and JWT_SECRET (a secret key for JWT).

  7. Deploy to Heroku:

    • Initialize a Git repository in your backend folder:

      bash
      Copy
      git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"

    • Link to Heroku:

      bash
      Copy
      heroku git:remote -a firstchoicehcmi-backend

    • Push to Heroku:

      bash
      Copy
      git push heroku main

  8. Test the Backend:

    • Visit https://firstchoicehcmi-backend.herokuapp.com/api/login to ensure it’s running.

1.2 Deploy Frontend to Netlify

  1. Create a Netlify Account: Sign up at Netlify.

  2. Install Netlify CLI:

    bash
    Copy
    npm install -g netlify-cli

  3. Login to Netlify:

    bash
    Copy
    netlify login

  4. Build the Frontend:

    • If you’re using a framework like React, build the project:

      bash
      Copy
      npm run build

    • For plain HTML/CSS/JS, ensure all files are in the frontend folder.

  5. Deploy to Netlify:

    • Run the following command in your frontend folder:

      bash
      Copy
      netlify deploy --prod

    • Follow the prompts to link your site and deploy.

  6. Update API Endpoints:

    • In frontend/scripts/script.js, replace http://localhost:5000 with your Heroku backend URL:

      javascript
      Copy
      const API_URL = 'https://firstchoicehcmi-backend.herokuapp.com';

  7. Test the Frontend:

    • Visit your Netlify site URL to ensure it’s working.

  name: String,

const router = express.Router();

module.exports = router;

    • Protect the route with middleware to ensure only admins can access it.

1.2 Create Admin Routes

Create a new file backend/routes/adminRoutes.js:

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const Employee = require('../models/Employee');

// Middleware to check if user is an admin
const isAdmin = (req, res, next) => {
  const token = req.headers.authorization.split(' ')[1];
  const decoded = jwt.verify(token, process.env.JWT_SECRET);
  Employee.findById(decoded.id, (err, employee) => {
    if (err || !employee || employee.role !== 'admin') {
      return res.status(403).json({ message: 'Access denied' });
    }
    next();
  });
};

// Get all employees
router.get('/employees', isAdmin, async (req, res) => {
  const employees = await Employee.find();
  res.json(employees);
});

// Get sign-in/sign-out logs for a specific employee
router.get('/logs/:employeeId', isAdmin, async (req, res) => {
  const employee = await Employee.findById(req.params.employeeId);
  if (!employee) {
    return res.status(404).json({ message: 'Employee not found' });
  }
  res.json({
    signInLogs: employee.signInLogs,
    signOutLogs: employee.signOutLogs,
  });
});

module.exports = router;

javascript
Copy
const API_URL = 'https://firstchoicehcmi-backend.herokuapp.com';

async function fetchEmployees() {
  const token = localStorage.getItem('token');
  const response = await fetch(`${API_URL}/api/admin/employees`, {
    headers: { 'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}` },
  });
  const employees = await response.json();
  renderEmployees(employees);
}

function renderEmployees(employees) {
  const tableBody = document.querySelector('#employee-table tbody');
  tableBody.innerHTML = employees.map(employee => `
    <tr>
      <td>${employee.name}</td>
      <td>${employee.email}</td>
      <td>${employee.role}</td>
      <td><button onclick="viewLogs('${employee._id}')">View Logs</button></td>
    </tr>
  `).join('');
}

async function viewLogs(employeeId) {
  const token = localStorage.getItem('token');
  const response = await fetch(`${API_URL}/api/admin/logs/${employeeId}`, {
    headers: { 'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}` },
  });
  const logs = await response.json();
  renderLogs(logs);
}

function renderLogs(logs) {
  const logsContainer = document.getElementById('logs-container');
  logsContainer.innerHTML = `
    <h3>Sign-In Logs</h3>
    <ul>${logs.signInLogs.map(log => `
      <li>${new Date(log.timestamp).toLocaleString()} - Latitude: ${log.location.latitude}, Longitude: ${log.location.longitude}</li>
    `).join('')}</ul>
    <h3>Sign-Out Logs</h3>
    <ul>${logs.signOutLogs.map(log => `
      <li>${new Date(log.timestamp).toLocaleString()} - Latitude: ${log.location.latitude}, Longitude: ${log.location.longitude}</li>
    `).join('')}</ul>
  `;
}

// Fetch employees on page load
fetchEmployees();

Feature 1: Push Notifications

We’ll use Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) to send push notifications to admins when employees sign in or sign out.

Step 1: Set Up Firebase

  1. Create a Firebase Project:

    • Go to the Firebase Console.

    • Click Add Project and follow the steps to create a new project.

  2. Add Firebase to Your Web App:

    • In the Firebase Console, click Add App and select Web.

    • Register your app and copy the Firebase configuration (you’ll need it for the frontend).

  3. Enable Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM):

    • In the Firebase Console, go to Project Settings → Cloud Messaging.

    • Generate a Server Key (you’ll need it for the backend).

Step 2: Update the Frontend

  1. Add Firebase SDK:

    • Include the Firebase SDK in your frontend/index.html:

      html
      Copy
      <script src="https://www.gstatic.com/firebasejs/9.6.10/firebase-app.js"></script>
<script src="https://www.gstatic.com/firebasejs/9.6.10/firebase-messaging.js"></script>
      Run HTML

  2. Initialize Firebase:

    • Add the following code to frontend/scripts/script.js:

      javascript
      Copy
      const firebaseConfig = {
  apiKey: "YOUR_API_KEY",
  authDomain: "YOUR_AUTH_DOMAIN",
  projectId: "YOUR_PROJECT_ID",
  storageBucket: "YOUR_STORAGE_BUCKET",
  messagingSenderId: "YOUR_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID",
  appId: "YOUR_APP_ID",
};

// Initialize Firebase
const app = firebase.initializeApp(firebaseConfig);
const messaging = firebase.messaging();

// Request permission for notifications
async function requestNotificationPermission() {
  const permission = await Notification.requestPermission();
  if (permission === 'granted') {
    console.log('Notification permission granted.');
    const token = await messaging.getToken();
    console.log('FCM Token:', token);
    // Send the token to your backend for later use
    await fetch('/api/save-fcm-token', {
      method: 'POST',
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
      body: JSON.stringify({ token }),
    });
  } else {
    console.log('Unable to get permission to notify.');
  }
}

requestNotificationPermission();

  3. Handle Incoming Notifications:

    • Add the following code to listen for notifications:

      javascript
      Copy
      messaging.onMessage((payload) => {
  console.log('Message received:', payload);
  new Notification(payload.notification.title, {
    body: payload.notification.body,
  });
});

Step 3: Update the Backend

  1. Save FCM Tokens:

    • Add a route to save FCM tokens in backend/routes/employeeRoutes.js:

      javascript
      Copy
      router.post('/save-fcm-token', async (req, res) => {
  const { token } = req.body;
  const employeeId = req.user.id; // Assuming you have user info in the request
  await Employee.findByIdAndUpdate(employeeId, { fcmToken: token });
  res.json({ message: 'FCM token saved' });

      javascript
      Copy
      const admin = require('firebase-admin');
const serviceAccount = require('./path/to/serviceAccountKey.json');

  credential: admin.credential.cert(serviceAccount),
});

async function sendNotification(token, title, body) {
  const message = {
    notification: { title, body },
    token,
  };
  await admin.messaging().send(message);
}

Feature 2: Reporting

We’ll generate PDF reports for employee attendance and GPS logs using the pdf-lib library.

Step 1: Install Dependencies

bash
Copy
npm install pdf-lib

Step 2: Add Reporting Route

  1. Create a Route:

    • Add the following code to backend/routes/adminRoutes.js:

      javascript
      Copy
      const { PDFDocument } = require('pdf-lib');

router.get('/report/:employeeId', isAdmin, async (req, res) => {
  const employee = await Employee.findById(req.params.employeeId);
  if (!employee) {
    return res.status(404).json({ message: 'Employee not found' });
  }

  // Create a PDF
  const pdfDoc = await PDFDocument.create();
  const page = pdfDoc.addPage();
  const { width, height } = page.getSize();
  page.drawText(`Attendance Report for ${employee.name}`, { x: 50, y: height - 50, size: 24 });

  // Add sign-in/sign-out logs
  let y = height - 100;
  employee.signInLogs.forEach((log) => {
    page.drawText(`Signed in at ${new Date(log.timestamp).toLocaleString()}`, { x: 50, y, size: 12 });
    y -= 20;
  });
  employee.signOutLogs.forEach((log) => {
    page.drawText(`Signed out at ${new Date(log.timestamp).toLocaleString()}`, { x: 50, y, size: 12 });
    y -= 20;
  });

  // Save and send the PDF
  const pdfBytes = await pdfDoc.save();
  res.setHeader('Content-Type', 'application/pdf');
  res.send(pdfBytes);
});

Also make it. easy for us to be able to keep track of interviews that interviews that are confirmed. Good dates, time. connected to the calendar. and setting where we have. the option. to send reminders. and increments of 15 minutes. 15 minutes.

To make it easy for you to track interviews, manage confirmed dates and times, connect to a calendar, and send reminders at 15-minute increments, we’ll integrate a calendar and reminder system into your employee portal. Here's how we can implement this feature:

Feature: Interview Scheduling and Reminders

Key Functionality

  1. Schedule Interviews:

    • Add, edit, and delete interview slots.

    • Connect to a calendar (e.g., Google Calendar) for seamless scheduling.

  2. Send Reminders:

    • Automatically send reminders to interviewers and candidates at 15-minute intervals before the interview.

  3. Track Interviews:

    • View a list of confirmed interviews with details like date, time, candidate name, and interviewer.

Step 1: Update the Backend

1.1 Add Interview Schema

Update the database schema to include interviews. Add the following to backend/models/Interview.js:

javascript
Copy
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const interviewSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  candidateName: { type: String, required: true },
  interviewerId: { type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId, ref: 'Employee', required: true },
  date: { type: Date, required: true },
  duration: { type: Number, default: 60 }, // Duration in minutes
  status: { type: String, enum: ['scheduled', 'completed', 'canceled'], default: 'scheduled' },
  reminders: [{ type: Date }], // Reminder timestamps
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('Interview', interviewSchema);

1.2 Add Interview Routes

Create a new file backend/routes/interviewRoutes.js:

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const Interview = require('../models/Interview');
const { sendNotification } = require('../utils/notifications');

// Schedule an interview
router.post('/schedule', async (req, res) => {
  const { candidateName, interviewerId, date, duration } = req.body;
  const interview = new Interview({ candidateName, interviewerId, date, duration });
  await interview.save();
  res.json(interview);
});

// Get all interviews
router.get('/', async (req, res) => {
  const interviews = await Interview.find().populate('interviewerId', 'name email');
  res.json(interviews);
});

// Send reminders
router.post('/send-reminders', async (req, res) => {
  const interviews = await Interview.find({ status: 'scheduled' });
  const now = new Date();
  interviews.forEach(async (interview) => {
    const timeDiff = interview.date - now; // Time difference in milliseconds
    if (timeDiff > 0 && timeDiff <= 15 * 60 * 1000) { // 15 minutes before
      await sendNotification(
        interview.interviewerId.fcmToken,
        'Interview Reminder',
        `You have an interview with ${interview.candidateName} in 15 minutes.`
      );
      interview.reminders.push(new Date());
      await interview.save();
    }
  });
  res.json({ message: 'Reminders sent' });
});

module.exports = router;

1.3 Add Interview Routes to Server

Update backend/server.js to include the interview routes:

javascript
Copy
const interviewRoutes = require('./routes/interviewRoutes');
app.use('/api/interviews', interviewRoutes);

javascript
Copy
const API_URL = 'https://firstchoicehcmi-backend.herokuapp.com';

document.getElementById('schedule-form').addEventListener('submit', async (e) => {
  e.preventDefault();
  const formData = new FormData(e.target);
  const response = await fetch(`${API_URL}/api/interviews/schedule`, {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify(Object.fromEntries(formData)),
  });
  const data = await response.json();
  if (response.ok) {
    alert('Interview scheduled successfully!');
    window.location.href = '/';
  } else {
    alert('Error scheduling interview');
  }
});

// Populate interviewers
async function populateInterviewers() {
  const response = await fetch(`${API_URL}/api/admin/employees`);
  const employees = await response.json();
  const select = document.getElementById('interviewer-id');
  select.innerHTML = employees.map(employee => `
    <option value="${employee._id}">${employee.name}</option>
  `).join('');
}

populateInterviewers();

Step 3: Integrate with Google Calendar

3.1 Use Google Calendar API

  1. Enable Google Calendar API:

    • Go to the Google Cloud Console.

    • Enable the Google Calendar API for your project.

  2. Authenticate and Authorize:

    • Use OAuth 2.0 to authenticate and authorize access to Google Calendar.

3.2 Add Calendar Integration to Backend

Update the interview scheduling route in backend/routes/interviewRoutes.js:

javascript
Copy
const { google } = require('googleapis');

async function addToGoogleCalendar(interview) {
  const auth = new google.auth.OAuth2(
    process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID,
    process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET,
    process.env.GOOGLE_REDIRECT_URI
  );
  auth.setCredentials({ refresh_token: process.env.GOOGLE_REFRESH_TOKEN });

  const calendar = google.calendar({ version: 'v3', auth });
  const event = {
    summary: `Interview with ${interview.candidateName}`,
    start: { dateTime: interview.date.toISOString() },
    end: { dateTime: new Date(interview.date.getTime() + interview.duration * 60000).toISOString() },
  };
  await calendar.events.insert({
    calendarId: 'primary',
    resource: event,
  });
}

// Update the schedule route
router.post('/schedule', async (req, res) => {
  const { candidateName, interviewerId, date, duration } = req.body;
  const interview = new Interview({ candidateName, interviewerId, date, duration });
  await interview.save();
  await addToGoogleCalendar(interview); // Add to Google Calendar
  res.json(interview);
});

Yes, we can integrate some of the features from RingCentral (like call management, dialing, and call tracking) into the website we’re creating for First Choice Staffing. RingCentral provides APIs that allow developers to embed its functionality into custom applications. Here's how we can implement some of these features:

Key RingCentral Features to Integrate

  1. Click-to-Call:

    • Allow users to make calls directly from the website using RingCentral's dialer.

  2. Call Logs:

    • Display call history and logs for employees and admins.

  3. Call Recording:

    • Record calls and store them for future reference.

Step 1: Set Up RingCentral Developer Account

  1. Create a RingCentral Developer Account:

    • Go to the RingCentral Developer Portal and sign up.

  2. Create an App:

    • Create a new app and note down the Client ID and Client Secret.

  3. Enable Permissions:

    • Enable permissions for features like Call Control, SMS, and Call Logs.

Step 2: Integrate RingCentral APIs

2.1 Install RingCentral SDK

Install the RingCentral SDK in your backend:

bash
Copy
npm install @ringcentral/sdk

2.2 Authenticate with RingCentral

Add authentication logic to your backend (backend/server.js):

javascript
Copy
const RingCentral = require('@ringcentral/sdk').SDK;

const rcsdk = new RingCentral({
  server: 'https://platform.ringcentral.com',
  clientId: process.env.RINGCENTRAL_CLIENT_ID,
  clientSecret: process.env.RINGCENTRAL_CLIENT_SECRET,
});

const platform = rcsdk.platform();

async function loginToRingCentral() {
  await platform.login({
    username: process.env.RINGCENTRAL_USERNAME,
    extension: process.env.RINGCENTRAL_EXTENSION,
    password: process.env.RINGCENTRAL_PASSWORD,
  });
  console.log('Logged in to RingCentral');
}

loginToRingCentral();

2.3 Add Click-to-Call Feature

Add a route to initiate calls in backend/routes/ringcentralRoutes.js:

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const platform = require('../utils/ringcentral');

// Make a call
router.post('/make-call', async (req, res) => {
  const { phoneNumber } = req.body;
  try {
    const response = await platform.post('/restapi/v1.0/account/~/extension/~/ring-out', {
      from: { phoneNumber: process.env.RINGCENTRAL_USERNAME },
      to: { phoneNumber },
      playPrompt: true,
    });
    res.json(response.data);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ message: 'Error making call', error });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

2.4 Add Call Logs

Add a route to fetch call logs in backend/routes/ringcentralRoutes.js:

javascript
Copy
// Get call logs
router.get('/call-logs', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const response = await platform.get('/restapi/v1.0/account/~/extension/~/call-log');
    res.json(response.data.records);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ message: 'Error fetching call logs', error });
  }
});

Step 3: Update the Frontend

3.1 Add Click-to-Call Button

Add a click-to-call button to your frontend (frontend/scripts/script.js):

javascript
Copy
document.getElementById('call-button').addEventListener('click', async () => {
  const phoneNumber = document.getElementById('phone-number').value;
  const response = await fetch('/api/ringcentral/make-call', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({ phoneNumber }),
  });
  const data = await response.json();
  if (response.ok) {
    alert('Call initiated!');
  } else {
    alert('Error making call');
  }
});

Update the JavaScript to fetch and display call logs (frontend/scripts/script.js):

javascript
Copy
async function fetchCallLogs() {
  const response = await fetch('/api/ringcentral/call-logs');
  const logs = await response.json();
  const tableBody = document.querySelector('#call-log-table tbody');
  tableBody.innerHTML = logs.map(log => `
    <tr>
      <td>${log.from.phoneNumber}</td>
      <td>${log.to.phoneNumber}</td>
      <td>${log.duration} seconds</td>
      <td>${log.result}</td>
    </tr>
  `).join('');
}

fetchCallLogs();

A. Database Connection (config/db.js)

javascript
Copy
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const connectDB = async () => {
  try {
    await mongoose.connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI || 'mongodb://localhost:27017/firstchoice', {
      useNewUrlParser: true,
      useUnifiedTopology: true,
    });
    console.log('MongoDB Connected');
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('MongoDB Connection Error:', err);
  }
};

module.exports = connectDB;

B. Employee Model (models/Employee.js)

javascript
Copy
const mongoose = require('mongoose');
const bcrypt = require('bcryptjs');

const employeeSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: { type: String, required: true },
  email: { type: String, required: true, unique: true },
  password: { type: String, required: true },
  role: { type: String, enum: ['employee', 'admin'], default: 'employee' },
  signInLogs: [{
    timestamp: { type: Date, default: Date.now },
    location: { lat: Number, lng: Number }
  }],
  signOutLogs: [{
    timestamp: { type: Date, default: Date.now },
    location: { lat: Number, lng: Number }
  }]
});

// Hash password before saving
employeeSchema.pre('save', async function (next) {
  if (this.isModified('password')) {
    this.password = await bcrypt.hash(this.password, 10);
  }
  next();
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('Employee', employeeSchema);

C. Authentication Middleware (middleware/auth.js)

javascript
Copy
const jwt = require('jsonwebtoken');
const Employee = require('../models/Employee');

const auth = async (req, res, next) => {
  try {
    const token = req.header('Authorization').replace('Bearer ', '');
    const decoded = jwt.verify(token, process.env.JWT_SECRET);
    const employee = await Employee.findOne({ _id: decoded.id, 'tokens.token': token });

    if (!employee) throw new Error();
    req.employee = employee;
    req.token = token;
    next();
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(401).json({ error: 'Authentication failed' });
  }
};

module.exports = auth;

D. Auth Routes (routes/authRoutes.js)

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const Employee = require('../models/Employee');
const jwt = require('jsonwebtoken');

// Employee Login
router.post('/login', async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  try {
    const employee = await Employee.findOne({ email });
    if (!employee || !(await bcrypt.compare(password, employee.password))) {
      return res.status(400).json({ error: 'Invalid credentials' });
    }
    const token = jwt.sign({ id: employee._id }, process.env.JWT_SECRET);
    res.json({ employee, token });
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Server error' });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

File Structure:

A. Login Component (components/Login.js)

javascript
Copy
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { login } from '../services/api';

const Login = () => {
  const [email, setEmail] = useState('');
  const [password, setPassword] = useState('');

  const handleSubmit = async (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    try {
      const { employee, token } = await login(email, password);
      localStorage.setItem('token', token);
      window.location.href = '/dashboard';
    } catch (err) {
      alert('Login failed');
    }
  };

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
      <input type="email" placeholder="Email" value={email} onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)} required />
      <input type="password" placeholder="Password" value={password} onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)} required />
      <button type="submit">Login</button>
    </form>
  );
};

export default Login;

B. GPS Tracking Component (components/MapTracker.js)

javascript
Copy
import React, { useEffect } from 'react';
import { MapContainer, TileLayer, Marker } from 'react-leaflet';
import 'leaflet/dist/leaflet.css';
import L from 'leaflet';

const MapTracker = ({ onLocationUpdate }) => {
  useEffect(() => {
    navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(
      (position) => {
        const { latitude, longitude } = position.coords;
        onLocationUpdate(latitude, longitude);
      },
      (err) => console.error('GPS Error:', err)
    );
  }, []);

  return (
    <MapContainer center={[51.505, -0.09]} zoom={13} style={{ height: '400px', width: '100%' }}>
      <TileLayer url="https://{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png" />
    </MapContainer>
  );
};

export default MapTracker;

2. Code for Feature 1: Employee Login/Signup

Backend (Node.js/Express)

File: backend/routes/authRoutes.js

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const bcrypt = require('bcryptjs');
const jwt = require('jsonwebtoken');
const Employee = require('../models/Employee');

// Signup
router.post('/signup', async (req, res) => {
  const { name, email, password } = req.body;
  try {
    const existingEmployee = await Employee.findOne({ email });
    if (existingEmployee) {
      return res.status(400).json({ error: 'Email already exists' });
    }
    const employee = new Employee({ name, email, password });
    await employee.save();
    res.status(201).json({ message: 'Employee created' });
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Server error' });
  }
});

// Login
router.post('/login', async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  try {
    const employee = await Employee.findOne({ email });
    if (!employee || !(await bcrypt.compare(password, employee.password))) {
      return res.status(400).json({ error: 'Invalid credentials' });
    }
    const token = jwt.sign({ id: employee._id }, process.env.JWT_SECRET, { expiresIn: '1h' });
    res.json({ token, employee: { id: employee._id, name: employee.name } });
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Server error' });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

Frontend (React.js)

File: frontend/src/components/Login.js

javascript
Copy
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import axios from 'axios';
import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom';

const Login = () => {
  const [email, setEmail] = useState('');
  const [password, setPassword] = useState('');
  const navigate = useNavigate();

  const handleSubmit = async (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    try {
      const response = await axios.post('http://localhost:5000/api/auth/login', { email, password });
      localStorage.setItem('token', response.data.token);
      navigate('/dashboard');
    } catch (err) {
      alert('Login failed');
    }
  };

  return (
    <div className="login-form">
      <h2>Employee Login</h2>
      <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
        <input
          type="email"
          placeholder="Email"
          value={email}
          onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)}
          required
        />
        <input
          type="password"
          placeholder="Password"
          value={password}
          onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
          required
        />
        <button type="submit">Login</button>
      </form>
    </div>
  );
};

export default Login;

Let’s build Feature 2: GPS Tracking next. Here’s what you need:

Backend (Add GPS Route)

File: backend/routes/gpsRoutes.js

javascript
Copy
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const auth = require('../middleware/auth');
const Employee = require('../models/Employee');

// Clock In
router.post('/clock-in', auth, async (req, res) => {
  const { lat, lng } = req.body;
  try {
    const employee = await Employee.findById(req.employee.id);
    employee.signInLogs.push({ location: { lat, lng } });
    await employee.save();
    res.json({ message: 'Clocked in successfully' });
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Server error' });
  }
});

// Clock Out
router.post('/clock-out', auth, async (req, res) => {
  const { lat, lng } = req.body;
  try {
    const employee = await Employee.findById(req.employee.id);
    employee.signOutLogs.push({ location: { lat, lng } });
    await employee.save();
    res.json({ message: 'Clocked out successfully' });
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Server error' });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

Frontend (GPS Component)

File: frontend/src/components/GPSTracker.js

javascript
Copy
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import axios from 'axios';

const GPSTracker = () => {
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const handleClockIn = async () => {
    setLoading(true);
    try {
      navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(async (position) => {
        const { latitude, longitude } = position.coords;
        await axios.post('/api/gps/clock-in', { lat: latitude, lng: longitude });
        alert('Clocked in!');
      });
    } catch (err) {
      alert('Error clocking in');
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={handleClockIn} disabled={loading}>
        {loading ? 'Clocking In...' : 'Clock In'}
      </button>
    </div>
  );
};

export default GPSTracker;

3.1 Common Issues & Fixes

IssueSolution
Backend CORS ErrorsAdd app.use(cors()) in server.js and whitelist frontend URL in Heroku.
MongoDB Connection FailuresCheck MONGODB_URI and ensure MongoDB is running (local or Atlas).
GPS Permissions DeniedEnsure HTTPS is used (browsers block GPS on HTTP).
Heroku Deployment CrashesCheck logs: heroku logs --tail.

1. AI Candidate Matching

Goal: Automatically match candidates to job openings based on skills, location, and availability.

Technical Implementation

  1. Data Collection:

    • Candidate Profiles: Resumes, skills, certifications, preferred locations.

    • Job Openings: Required skills, location, shift times, experience level.

  2. Machine Learning Model:

    • Tools: Python’s scikit-learn or TensorFlow.js (for browser-based models).

    • Steps:

      python
      Copy
      # Example pseudocode for candidate matching
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity

# Vectorize job requirements and candidate skills
job_description = "nurse, CPR certified, night shifts"
candidate_skills = ["RN License", "CPR Certified", "5 years ICU experience"]

vectorizer = TfidfVectorizer()
vectors = vectorizer.fit_transform([job_description] + candidate_skills)

# Calculate similarity scores
similarity = cosine_similarity(vectors[0:1], vectors[1:])
print(similarity)  # Rank candidates by highest score

  3. Integration with Backend:

    • Add a /api/match-candidates endpoint to fetch and rank candidates.

    • Use pre-trained models or fine-tune with historical hiring data.

  4. Ethical Considerations:

    • Audit the model for bias (e.g., gender, race).

const axios = require('axios');

async function syncToQuickBooks(employeeId, hoursWorked) {
  const response = await axios.post('https://quickbooks.api.intuit.com/v3/company/1234567890/timeactivity', {
    "EmployeeRef": employeeId,
    "Hours": hoursWorked,
    "StartTime": "2023-10-01T09:00:00",
    "EndTime": "2023-10-01T17:00:00"
  }, {
    headers: { 'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN' }
  });
  return response.data;
}

2. Polished Code Snippets

AI Candidate Matching (Python)

python
Copy
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity

def match_candidates(job_description, candidates_df):
    # Vectorize text
    vectorizer = TfidfVectorizer(stop_words='english')
    job_vector = vectorizer.fit_transform([job_description])
    candidate_vectors = vectorizer.transform(candidates_df['skills'])

    # Calculate similarity
    similarity_scores = cosine_similarity(job_vector, candidate_vectors)
    candidates_df['score'] = similarity_scores[0]
    
    # Return top 5 matches
    return candidates_df.sort_values(by='score', ascending=False).head(5)

# Example usage
candidates = pd.DataFrame({
    'name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'skills': ['nurse, CPR certified', 'RN, ICU experience', 'phlebotomist, lab tech']
})
job_desc = "RN with ICU experience and CPR certification"

top_matches = match_candidates(job_desc, candidates)
print(top_matches[['name', 'score']])

Payroll Sync (Node.js + QuickBooks API)

javascript
Copy
const axios = require('axios');
const Employee = require('../models/Employee');

async function syncPayroll(employeeId) {
  try {
    const employee = await Employee.findById(employeeId);
    const totalHours = calculateHours(employee.signInLogs, employee.signOutLogs);

    // Sync to QuickBooks
    const response = await axios.post(
      'https://quickbooks.api.intuit.com/v3/company/1234567890/timeactivity',
      {
        "EmployeeRef": employee.quickbooksId,
        "Hours": totalHours,
        "StartTime": employee.signInLogs[0].timestamp,
        "EndTime": employee.signOutLogs.slice(-1)[0].timestamp,
      },
      { headers: { 'Authorization': `Bearer ${process.env.QUICKBOOKS_TOKEN}` } }
    );

    return response.data;
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Payroll sync failed:', err);
    throw err;
  }
}

// Calculate hours from GPS logs
function calculateHours(signIns, signOuts) {
  const start = new Date(signIns[0].timestamp);
  const end = new Date(signOuts.slice(-1)[0].timestamp);
  return (end - start) / (1000 * 60 * 60); // Convert ms to hours
}

Issue 1: GPS Tracking Not Working

  • Symptoms: Coordinates not saving to MongoDB.

  • Debug Steps:

    1. Check browser console for geolocation errors.

    2. Ensure the backend endpoint /api/gps/clock-in is receiving POST requests.

    3. Verify MongoDB connection in Heroku logs:

      bash
      Copy
      heroku logs --tail --app firstchoice-backend

Issue 2: QuickBooks Payroll Sync Failing

  • Symptoms: 401 Unauthorized errors.

  • Debug Steps:

    1. Confirm the QuickBooks access token is valid.

    2. Check permissions for the QuickBooks API scope.

    3. Test the API in Postman:

      javascript
      Copy
      POST https://quickbooks.api.intuit.com/v3/company/1234567890/timeactivity
Headers: { "Authorization": "Bearer YOUR_TOKEN" }

Issue 3: AI Matching Low Accuracy

  • Symptoms: Poor candidate-job matches.

  • Debug Steps:

    1. Check the training data for biases (e.g., overrepresenting certain roles).

    2. Test the cosine similarity scores with sample data.

      python
      Copy
      print(f"Top match: {top_matches[0]['name']} with score {top_matches[0]['score']}")

2. Troubleshooting the GPS Clock-In Error

Issue: GPS coordinates not saving to MongoDB.
Debugging Steps:

  1. Frontend Check:

    • Open Chrome DevTools (F12 → Console tab).

    • Verify the browser is allowing GPS permissions.

    • Check if the POST /api/gps/clock-in request is being sent.

  2. Backend Check:

    • Add logging to clock-in route:

      javascript
      Copy
      router.post('/clock-in', auth, async (req, res) => {
  console.log('Received GPS data:', req.body); // Debug line
  // ... rest of the code
});

    • Check Heroku logs:

      bash
      Copy
      heroku logs --tail --app firstchoice-backend

  3. MongoDB Check:

    • Ensure the MongoDB URI in Heroku is correct:

      bash
      Copy
      heroku config:get MONGODB_URI

    • Test the connection locally:

      bash
      Copy
      mongosh "mongodb://localhost:27017/firstchoice"

Fix:

  • If the issue is CORS, add app.use(cors()) in server.js.

  • If MongoDB is timing out, upgrade to MongoDB Atlas.
